markdownRemark.html:
Describing a Linear Combination

  • A linear combination is a vector representing any combination of a set of vectors using vector addition or scalar multiplication
  • In other words, a linear combination is a sum of scaled vectors within a vector space
  • More specifically, a linear combination is a mapped output of a sum of scaled vectors from vector space VVV to somewhere else in that same vector space VVV
  • As stated previously, a linear combination is a mapped output of a sum of scaled vectors function
  • The input of the function is a set of vectors from some vector space VVV
  • The output of the function is the linear combination (of those input vectors) that is also from the same vector space VVV
  • Therefore, a linear combination just represents some new vector in the same vector space VVV (as the vector space VVV of the input vectors)
  • Specifically, the sum of scaled vectors function refers to the following:
f(v)=∑αivif(v) = \sum \alpha_{i}v_{i}f(v)=∑αi​vi​
  • Where viv_{i}vi​ are the vectors
  • Where αi\alpha_{i}αi​ are the scalars
  • Where f(v)f(v)f(v) is our linear combination

An Abstract Example of Linear Combinations

  • Very roughly speaking, our input vectors can be thought of as some English words
  • And, our linear combination can be thought of as a different, yet related, English word that is essentially the outcome of combining all of those words together
  • In our example, our English words could be quick, spotted, and cat and our new related English word (or our linear combination) could be cheetah:
quick+spotted+cat=cheetahquick + spotted + cat = cheetahquick+spotted+cat=cheetah
  • In this example, the initial English words and resultant English word mean very different things on their own, but are at least represented in the same language so we can still understand it
  • In other words, our new cheetah word is still in the same vector space as our initial words quick, spotted, and cat

  • Similar to how the input of our sum-of-scaled-vectors function is a set of vectors from the vector space VVV, our input is a set of words from the English language

    • Here, our vector space represents all languages, and our specific vector space is English
  • Similar to how the output of our sum of scaled vectors function is a linear combination of our input vectors, which is also from the same vector space VVV, our output is also an English word
  • Therefore, our linear combination in this very abstract example represents some new word that remains English

Where does Linear Combination Get its Name?

  • The linear part of linear combination refers to scalar multiplication

    • Specifically, it comes from linearly scaling a vector to output another vector
    • In other words, the resultant vector represents a scaled version of a vector
    • As a reminder, linear scaling refers to multiplying constants by a vector (or variable in the general sense)

  • The combination part of linear combination refers to vector addition

    • Specifically, it comes from adding vectors together to output another vector
    • In other words, the resultant vector represents a (added) combination of a set of other vectors

Example of Linear Combinations

  • Let's say we have the following vectors:
v1=[123],v2=[351],v3=[008]v_{1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix}, v_{2} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 5 \cr 1 \end{bmatrix}, v_{3} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \cr 0 \cr 8 \end{bmatrix}v1​=⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​,v2​=⎣⎢⎡​351​⎦⎥⎤​,v3​=⎣⎢⎡​008​⎦⎥⎤​
  • Then the following vectors are linear combinations of v1,v2,v_{1}, v_{2},v1​,v2​, and v3v_{3}v3​:
b1=[369],b2=[3617],b3=[91611],b4=[123]b_{1} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 6 \cr 9 \end{bmatrix}, b_{2} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 6 \cr 17 \end{bmatrix}, b_{3} = \begin{bmatrix} 9 \cr 16 \cr 11 \end{bmatrix}, b_{4} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix}b1​=⎣⎢⎡​369​⎦⎥⎤​,b2​=⎣⎢⎡​3617​⎦⎥⎤​,b3​=⎣⎢⎡​91611​⎦⎥⎤​,b4​=⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​
  • Vector b1b_{1}b1​ is a linear combination of v1,v2,v_{1}, v_{2},v1​,v2​, and v3v_{3}v3​ because:
[369]=3[123]+0[351]+0[008]\begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 6 \cr 9 \end{bmatrix} = 3\begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix} + 0\begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 5 \cr 1 \end{bmatrix} + 0\begin{bmatrix} 0 \cr 0 \cr 8 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎢⎡​369​⎦⎥⎤​=3⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​+0⎣⎢⎡​351​⎦⎥⎤​+0⎣⎢⎡​008​⎦⎥⎤​
  • Vector b2b_{2}b2​ is a linear combination of v1,v2,v_{1}, v_{2},v1​,v2​, and v3v_{3}v3​ because:
[3617]=3[123]+0[351]+1[008]\begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 6 \cr 17 \end{bmatrix} = 3\begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix} + 0\begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 5 \cr 1 \end{bmatrix} + 1\begin{bmatrix} 0 \cr 0 \cr 8 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎢⎡​3617​⎦⎥⎤​=3⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​+0⎣⎢⎡​351​⎦⎥⎤​+1⎣⎢⎡​008​⎦⎥⎤​
  • Vector b3b_{3}b3​ is a linear combination of v1,v2,v_{1}, v_{2},v1​,v2​, and v3v_{3}v3​ because:
[91611]=3[123]+2[351]+0[008]\begin{bmatrix} 9 \cr 16 \cr 11 \end{bmatrix} = 3\begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix} + 2\begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 5 \cr 1 \end{bmatrix} + 0\begin{bmatrix} 0 \cr 0 \cr 8 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎢⎡​91611​⎦⎥⎤​=3⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​+2⎣⎢⎡​351​⎦⎥⎤​+0⎣⎢⎡​008​⎦⎥⎤​
  • Vector b4b_{4}b4​ is a linear combination of v1,v2,v_{1}, v_{2},v1​,v2​, and v3v_{3}v3​ because:
[123]=1[123]+0[351]+0[008]\begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix} = 1\begin{bmatrix} 1 \cr 2 \cr 3 \end{bmatrix} + 0\begin{bmatrix} 3 \cr 5 \cr 1 \end{bmatrix} + 0\begin{bmatrix} 0 \cr 0 \cr 8 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​=1⎣⎢⎡​123​⎦⎥⎤​+0⎣⎢⎡​351​⎦⎥⎤​+0⎣⎢⎡​008​⎦⎥⎤​

Describing a Span

  • The span of two vectors vvv and www (or spanning set) is the set of all of their linear combinations

  • We can use span in the following contexts to mean the same thing:

    • The span of the two vectors v=[1,1]v = [1, 1]v=[1,1] and w=[1,−2]w = [1, -2]w=[1,−2] makes up R2\R^{2}R2
    • The spanning set of v=[1,1]v = [1, 1]v=[1,1] and w=[1,−2]w = [1, -2]w=[1,−2] makes up R2\R^{2}R2
    • The two vectors v=[1,1]v = [1, 1]v=[1,1] and w=[1,−2]w = [1, -2]w=[1,−2] span R2\R^{2}R2

  • We can think of the following to be true:

    • A single vector is a point
    • A set of vectors is a set of points
    • A span of a single vector is a line
    • A span of a set of vectors is a plane
  • Since a one dimensional plane is a line, a span of a one dimensional vector can be thought of as a line

Basis Vectors

  • A set of vectors in a vector space VVV is a basis if every vector from VVV can be written in a unique way as a linear combination of vectors of VVV
  • A unit vector is a vector of length 1
  • A standard basis is a set of unit unique vectors pointing in each direction of the axes
  • A standard basis is one of many possible bases for some vector space VVV
  • The following are examples of bases of R3\R^{3}R3:
b1=[1011200−13],b2=[200050004],b_{1} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \cr 1 & 2 & 0 \cr 0 & -1 & 3 \end{bmatrix}, b_{2} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \cr 0 & 5 & 0 \cr 0 & 0 & 4 \end{bmatrix},b1​=⎣⎢⎡​110​02−1​103​⎦⎥⎤​,b2​=⎣⎢⎡​200​050​004​⎦⎥⎤​, b3=[12−2011−1−14],b4=[100010001]b_{3} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -2 \cr 0 & 1 & 1 \cr -1 & -1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}, b_{4} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \cr 0 & 1 & 0 \cr 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}b3​=⎣⎢⎡​10−1​21−1​−214​⎦⎥⎤​,b4​=⎣⎢⎡​100​010​001​⎦⎥⎤​
  • These are all a basis of R3\R^{3}R3 because each set of vectors of bbb is a linear combination of the following:
I4=[100010001]I_{4} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \cr 0 & 1 & 0 \cr 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}I4​=⎣⎢⎡​100​010​001​⎦⎥⎤​

Examples of Standard Bases

  • The following is the standard basis of R3\R^{3}R3:
b=[100010001]b = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \cr 0 & 1 & 0 \cr 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}b=⎣⎢⎡​100​010​001​⎦⎥⎤​
  • The following is the standard basis of R2\R^{2}R2:
b=[1001]b = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 \cr 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}b=[10​01​]
